a.g: The command of Allah is coming, so be not impatient for it. Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him.
He sends down the angels, with the inspiration of His command, upon whom He wills of His servants, [telling them], "Warn that there is no deity except Me; so fear Me."
He created the heavens and earth in truth. High is He above what they associate with Him.
He created man from a sperm-drop; then at once, he is a clear adversary.
And the grazing livestock He has created for you; in them is warmth and [numerous] benefits, and from them you eat.
And for you in them is [the enjoyment of] beauty when you bring them in [for the evening] and when you send them out [to pasture].
And they carry your loads to a land you could not have reached except with difficulty to yourselves. Indeed, your Lord is Kind and Merciful.
And [He created] the horses, mules and donkeys for you to ride and [as] adornment. And He creates that which you do not know.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Meditation
And the existence of all things is a light from the lights of His Essence, Exalted and Holy, since the subsistence of the existence of things is by His Self-Subsisting Essence, just as the subsistence of the light of bodies is by the light of the sun that illuminates by itself. And whenever some of the sun is uncovered, it has become customary to place a basin of water so that the sun may be seen in it and it becomes possible to look at it, so the water becomes a medium that slightly reduces the light of the sun until it can be endured to look at. Likewise, actions are a medium through which we witness the attributes of the Actor, and we are not dazzled by the lights of the Essence after we have distanced ourselves from it through the medium of actions. This is the secret of His saying, peace be upon him: 'Reflect upon the creation of Allah and do not reflect upon the Essence of Allah, Exalted.' Explanation of the manner of reflecting upon the creation of Allah, Exalted. Know that everything in existence other than Allah, Exalted, is the action and creation of Allah, and every atom of the atoms, whether substance, accident, attribute, or described thing, contains wonders and marvels through which the wisdom, power, majesty, and greatness of Allah appear. Enumerating that is not possible, for if the sea were ink for that, the sea would be exhausted before a tenth of its tenth is exhausted. But we point to a summary of it so that it may serve as an example for what is beyond it. So we say: The created existents are divided into that whose origin is not known, so we cannot reflect upon it, and how many existents are there that we do not know, as Allah, Exalted, said: 'And He creates what you do not know. Glory be to Him who created all pairs from what the earth grows and from themselves and from what they do not know.' And He said: 'And We will develop you in what you do not know.' And into that whose origin and summary is known but whose details are not known, so we can reflect upon its details. And it is divided into what we perceive by the sense of sight and into what we do not perceive by sight. As for what we do not perceive by sight, such as the angels, jinn, devils, the Throne (Al-'Arsh), the Footstool (Al-Kursi), and other than that, the field of thought in these things is narrow and obscure, so let us turn to what is closer to comprehension, which is what is perceived by the sense of sight, and that is the seven heavens and the earth and what is between them. So the heavens are observed with their stars, sun, moon, movement, and rotation in their rising and setting; and the earth is observed with what is in it of its mountains, minerals, rivers, seas, animals, and plants; and what is between the sky and the earth, which is the atmosphere, is perceived with its clouds, rains, snows, thunder, lightning, thunderbolts, meteors, and stormy winds. These are the observable genera from the heavens and the earth and what is between them, and every genus of them divides into species, and every species divides into categories, and every category branches into varieties, and there is no end to the branching and division of that in the differences of its attributes, forms, and apparent and hidden meanings, and all of that is a field for thought. So not an atom moves in the heavens...

a.g: And upon Allah is the direction of the [right] way, and among the various paths are those deviating. And if He willed, He could have guided you all.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And upon Allah is the straightening of the path, and among them are deviant ones. And if He had willed, He would have guided you all. And Ali (may Allah honor his face) said: Desire (Hawa) is a partner of blindness. And from success (Tawfiq) is stopping at perplexity. And an excellent dispeller of worry is certainty (Yaqin). And the consequence of lying is regret. And in truthfulness is safety. A distant lord is closer than a close one, and a stranger is one who has no beloved. And the truthful friend (Sadiq) is one who is truthful in his absence. And do not let a beloved be lacking in you due to bad suspicion. An excellent character is generosity (Takrim). And modesty (Haya) is a means to every beautiful thing. And the most secure bond is piety (Taqwa). And the most secure means you have taken is a means between you and Allah. Indeed, what you have from your worldly life is what you have rectified with your abode. And provision (Rizq) is of two types: provision you seek and provision that seeks you. So if you do not come to it, it will come to you. And if you are distressed over what has befallen you from what is in your hands, then do not be distressed over what has not reached you. And infer about what has not been from what has been, for matters are similar. And a person is pleased by attaining what would not have escaped him and is displeased by missing what he would not have attained. So what reaches you from your worldly life, do not excessively rejoice in it, and what escapes you from it, do not let your soul (Nafs) follow it with regret. And let your joy be in what you have sent forth and your regret over what you have left behind. And your occupation be for your hereafter and your concern in what is after death. And our purpose in transmitting these words is his saying: And from success (Tawfiq) is stopping at perplexity.

a.g: It is He who sends down rain from the sky; from it is drink and from it is foliage in which you pasture [animals].
He causes to grow for you thereby the crops, olives, palm trees, grapevines, and from all the fruits. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who give thought.
And He has subjected for you the night and day and the sun and moon, and the stars are subjected by His command. Indeed in that are signs for a people who reason.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

And the firmly established scholar (Alim) is the one who perceives that the sun, the moon, and the stars are subjugated by His command, glorified and exalted is He. The example of the weak person's view regarding the occurrence of sunlight following the rising of the sun is like an ant, if intellect were created for it and it were on the surface of a paper, and it looks at the blackness of the line being renewed, so it believes it is the action of the pen, and it does not ascend in its view to witnessing the fingers, then from them to the hand, then from them to the will (Iradah) that moves the hand, then from them to the writer who is capable (Qadir) and willing (Murid), then from him to the creator of the hand, the capability (Qudrah), and the will (Iradah). So most of the view of creation is restricted to the proximate, lowly causes, cut off from ascending to the causer of causes. This is one of the reasons for the prohibition regarding the stars.

a.g: And [He has subjected] whatever He multiplied for you on the earth of varying colors. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who remember.

And it is He who subjected the sea for you to eat from it tender meat and to extract from it ornaments which you wear. And you see the ships plowing through it, and [He subjected it] that you may seek of His bounty; and perhaps you will be grateful.
And He has cast into the earth firmly set mountains, lest it shift with you, and [made] rivers and roads, that you may be guided,
And landmarks. And by the stars they are [also] guided.
Then is He who creates like one who does not create? So will you not be reminded?
And if you should count the favors of Allah, you could not enumerate them. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.

And the origin of every arrangement and composition, and all of that is blessings from the Lord of lords and the Causer of causes. And were it not for His grace and generosity when He, the Exalted, said: "And those who strive in Us, We will surely guide them to Our ways" (Quran 29:69), we would not have been guided to this small portion of the blessings of Allah, the Exalted. And were it not for His isolating us from aspiring with the eye of greed to encompass the essence of His blessings, we would have yearned to seek encompassing and exhaustive enumeration. But He, the Exalted, isolated us by the decree of overpowering and power, so He, the Exalted, said: "And if you should count the blessings of Allah, you could not enumerate them" (Quran 16:18). So if we speak, it is by His permission that we expand; and if we remain silent, it is by His overpowering that we contract, for there is no giver of what He has withheld nor withholder of what He has given. And as you know that in every blink of an eye there are many blessings, so know that in every breath that expands and contracts there are two blessings: with its expansion, it expels the burnt smoke from the Heart (Qalb), and if it did not expel it, it would perish; and with its contraction, it gathers the spirit of air to the Heart (Qalb), and if its breathing passage were blocked, its Heart (Qalb) would burn from the cutting off of the spirit of air and its cooling from it, and it would perish. Rather, the day and night are twenty-four hours, and in every hour there are about a thousand breaths, and every breath is about ten moments, so upon you in every moment are thousands upon thousands of blessings in every part of the parts of your body, nay in every part of the parts of the world. So look: is it conceivable to enumerate that or not? And when the reality of His saying, the Exalted, was revealed to Moses, peace be upon him: 'And if you count the blessings of Allah, you cannot enumerate them' (Quran 16:18), he said: 'My God, how can I thank You when for every hair on my body there are two blessings: that You softened its root and that You blunted its tip.' And likewise, it has come in the tradition that whoever does not recognize the blessings of Allah in his food and drink, then his knowledge has diminished and his punishment has drawn near. And all that we have mentioned returns to food and drink, so consider what is other than them from the blessings by it, for the insightful one does not cast his eye in the world upon anything, nor does his thought touch upon an existent, except that he realizes that Allah has in it a blessing upon him. So let us leave exhaustive detailing, for it is aspiration in what is not attainable.

And since those causes are lengthy, a book like this cannot bear their exhaustive enumeration, so let us mention from them a model to understand by it the meaning of His saying, the Exalted: 'And if you count the blessings of Allah, you cannot enumerate them' (Quran 16:18). And by Allah is success. (Explanation of the aspect of the model in the abundance of Allah's blessings and their sequence and their departure from enumeration and counting) Know that we have gathered the blessings into sixteen types, and we made the health of the body a blessing from the blessings occurring in the later rank. So this single blessing, if we wanted to exhaustively enumerate the causes by which this blessing is completed, we would not be able to do so. But eating is one of the causes of health, so let us mention a portion from the totality of causes by which the blessing of eating is completed. It is not hidden that eating is an action, and every action of this type is a movement, and every movement necessarily has a moving body that is its instrument, and necessarily has a power (Qudrah) over the movement, and necessarily has a will (Iradah) for the movement, and necessarily has knowledge (Ilm) of what is intended and perception (Idrak) of it. And eating necessarily has food (MÄ'kul), and the food necessarily has an origin from which it is obtained, and necessarily has a maker (SÄni') who prepares it. So let us mention the causes of perception, then the causes of wills, then the causes of power, then the causes of food, by way of allusion, not by way of exhaustive enumeration. (The first aspect in Allah's blessings in creating the causes of perception) Know that Allah, the Exalted, created the plant, and it is more complete in existence than the stone, the clay, the iron, the copper, and the rest of the jewels that do not grow and do not nourish, for the plant...

And the totality of what we have known and what all creation has known, in addition to what they have not known of the blessings of Allah the Exalted, is less than a drop from an ocean. However, whoever knows something of this perceives a whiff of the meanings of His saying the Exalted: 'And if you should count the blessings of Allah, you could not enumerate them.' So it does not reach a part from the parts of the body except that it causes, upon its arrival in those parts, what is needed from it of sensory power, perception, power of movement, and others, like the lamp that is circulated in the corners of the house. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
And as for the second reason: which is his love for the one who has done good to him by supporting him with his wealth, speaking kindly to him, aiding him with his assistance, volunteering for his support, suppressing his enemies, undertaking to repel the harm of the wicked from him, and becoming a means to all his aspirations and purposes in himself, his children, and his relatives, then he is undoubtedly beloved to him. And this very thing necessitates that he should love none but Allah the Exalted, for if he knew with true knowledge, he would know that the one who does good to him is Allah the Exalted alone. As for the types of His benevolence to all His servants, I do not enumerate them, for no enumerator can encompass them, as the Exalted has said: "And if you should count the favors of Allah, you could not enumerate them." And we have pointed to a part of it in the Book of Gratitude. But we restrict ourselves now to clarifying that benevolence from people is not conceivable except metaphorically, and indeed the Benevolent One is Allah the Exalted.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And the worst types of arrogance (Kibr) are what prevent from benefiting from knowledge and accepting the truth and submitting to it. In it have come the verses which contain censure of arrogance (Kibr) and the arrogant ones. Allah the Exalted said: 'And the angels will be spreading their hands' up to His saying: 'and you were arrogant (Tastakbirun) about His signs.' Then He said: 'Enter the gates of Hell, abiding eternally therein, and wretched is the residence of the arrogant (Mutakabirin).' Then He informed that the most severely punished of the people of the Fire are the most insolent (Atiyan) against Allah the Exalted, so He said: 'Then We will surely extract from every sect those of them who were most insolent (Atiyan) against the Most Merciful.' And He the Exalted said: 'So those who do not believe in the Hereafter, their hearts (Qulub) are denying (Munkirah) and they are arrogant (Mustakbirun).' And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Those who were oppressed say to those who were arrogant (Istakbaru): "If not for you, we would have been believers."' And He the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who are arrogant (Yastakbirun) about My worship will enter Hell in humiliation.' And He the Exalted said: 'I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant (Yatakabbarun) in the earth without right.' It is said in the interpretation (Tafsir): I will lift the understanding of the Quran from their hearts (Qulub). And in some interpretations (Tafsir): I will veil their hearts (Qulub) from the dominion (Malakut). And Ibn Juraij said: I will turn them away from reflecting upon them and taking admonition from them. And therefore, Jesus (Isa) peace be upon him said: Indeed, the crop grows in the plain and does not grow upon the rock, likewise wisdom (Hikmah) works in the heart (Qalb) of the humble one and does not work in the heart (Qalb) of the arrogant one (Mutakabbir). Do you not see that whoever raises his head to the ceiling strikes it, and whoever lowers it is shaded and sheltered. So this is a parable he struck for the arrogant ones (Mutakabirin) and how they are deprived of wisdom (Hikmah). And therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) mentioned the rejection (Juhud) of the truth as part of the definition of arrogance (Kibr) and the uncovering of its reality, and he said: 'Whoever belittles the truth and looks down upon people.'

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Indeed, Allah has condemned arrogance in multiple places in His Book and condemned every tyrant who is arrogant. So He, the Exalted, said: "I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant on earth without right" and He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "Thus does Allah seal over every arrogant, tyrannical heart (Qalb)" and He, the Exalted, said: "And they sought victory, and every obstinate tyrant failed" and He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, He does not love the arrogant ones" and He, the Exalted, said: "They have certainly become arrogant within themselves and transgressed a great transgression" and He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, those who are arrogant toward My worship will enter Hell in humiliation." And the condemnation of arrogance in the Quran is abundant. And the Messenger of Allah ï­¬ said: "He will not enter Paradise who has in his heart (Qalb) the weight of a mustard seed of arrogance, and he will not enter the Fire who has in his heart (Qalb) the weight of a mustard seed of faith (Iman)."

a.g: And when it is said to them, "What has your Lord sent down?" They say, "Legends of the former peoples,"
That they may bear their own burdens in full on the Day of Resurrection and some of the burdens of those whom they misguide without knowledge. Unquestionably, evil is that which they bear.

Those before them had already plotted, but Allah came at their building from the foundations, so the roof fell upon them from above them, and the punishment came to them from where they did not perceive.

Then on the Day of Resurrection He will disgrace them and say, "Where are My 'partners' for whom you used to oppose [the believers]?" Those who were given knowledge will say, "Indeed disgrace, this Day, and evil are upon the disbelievers" -
The ones whom the angels take in death [while] wronging themselves, and [who] then offer submission, [saying], "We were not doing any evil." But, yes! Indeed, Allah is Knowing of what you used to do.

They fear their Lord above them, and they do what they are commanded.
And Allah has said, "Do not take for yourselves two deities. He is but one God, so fear only Me."
And to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth, and to Him is [due] worship constantly. Then is it other than Allah that you fear?
And whatever you have of favor - it is from Allah. Then when adversity touches you, to Him you cry for help.
Then when He removes the adversity from you, at once a party of you associates others with their Lord
So they will deny what We have given them. Then enjoy yourselves, for you are going to know.
And they assign to what they do not know a portion of that which We have provided them. By Allah, you will surely be questioned about what you used to invent.
And they attribute to Allah daughters - exalted is He - and for them is what they desire.
And when one of them is informed of [the birth of] a female, his face becomes dark, and he suppresses grief.
He hides himself from the people because of the ill of which he has been informed. Should he keep it in humiliation or bury it in the ground? Unquestionably, evil is what they decide.
For those who do not believe in the Hereafter is the description of evil; and for Allah is the highest attribute. And He is Exalted in Might, the Wise.

And if Allah were to impose blame on the people for their wrongdoing, He would not have left upon the earth any creature, but He defers them for a specified term. And when their term has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it].

And they attribute to Allah that which they dislike, and their tongues assert the lie that they will have the best [from Him]. Assuredly, they will have the Fire, and they will be [therein] neglected.

Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
Know that everything that can be imagined to be mixed with something else, when it becomes pure from its mixture and purified from it, is called pure (khalis), and the purified, purified action is called sincerity (ikhlas). Allah the Exalted said: 'From between dung and blood, pure milk, palatable to the drinkers.' For the purity of milk is that there is no mixture in it of blood and dung, and from everything that can mix with it. And sincerity (ikhlas) is opposed to association (shirk), so whoever is not sincere is an associator, except that association has degrees. Sincerity in monotheism (tawhid) is opposed to association in divinity, and association is of two kinds: hidden and apparent, and likewise sincerity. Sincerity and its opposite come upon the heart (qalb), so its place is the heart, and that only occurs in intentions and purposes. And the reality of intention has been mentioned, that it returns to responding to motives. So whenever the motive is single in detachment, the action emanating from it is called sincerity relative to what is intended. So whoever gives charity and his aim is purely ostentation (riya), he is sincere, and whoever's aim is purely drawing near to Allah the Exalted, he is sincere. But custom is established in specifying the name sincerity (ikhlas) to mean purifying the intention of drawing near to Allah the Exalted from all impurities, just as deviation (ilhad) is an expression for inclination, but custom specified it as inclination away from the truth. And whoever's motive is purely ostentation is exposed to destruction, and we are not speaking about it since we have mentioned what pertains to it in the Book of Ostentation from the quarter of destructives, and the least of its matters is what came in the report that the ostentatious will be called on the Day of Resurrection with four names: 'O ostentatious, O deceiver, O associator, O disbeliever.'

Praise be to Allah who created the human being from sticky clay and ringing clay, then fashioned his form in the best proportion and most perfect balance. So giving thanks (Shukr) is obedience (Taa'a), and complaining (Shakwa) is ugly disobedience (Ma'siya) from the people of religion (Ahl al-Din). And how could complaining (Shakwa) not be ugly from the King of Kings (Malik al-Muluk) in whose hand is everything, to an owned slave (Abd Mamlook) who is not capable of anything? So it is more appropriate for the servant (Abd) that if he does not excel in patience (Sabr) upon the trial (Bala) and the decree (Qada), and weakness leads him to complaining (Shakwa), that his complaint (Shakwa) be to Allah the Exalted, for He is the One who afflicts (Al-Mubli) and is capable of removing the trial (Bala), and the humility (Dhull) of the servant (Abd) to his Master (Mawla) is glorious, and complaining (Shakwa) to other than Him is humility (Dhull), and showing humility (Dhull) to a servant (Abd) while he is a servant (Abd) like him is ugly humility (Dhull). Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those you worship besides Allah do not possess for you [the power of] provision. So seek from Allah provision and worship Him and be grateful to Him.' {} And He said: 'Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah are servants like you.' {} So giving thanks (Shukr) by the tongue (Lisan) is from the totality of giving thanks (Shukr).

What is more humiliated than him if he knew himself? And how does arrogance befit him except due to his ignorance? This is his intermediate state, so let him contemplate it. As for his end and destination, it is death, alluded to by the saying of the Exalted: 'Then He causes him to die and buries him, then when He wills, He resurrects him.' Its meaning is that He strips him of his Spirit (Ruh), hearing, sight, knowledge, power, sensation, perception, and movement, so he returns as inanimate matter as he was at first, nothing remains except the form of his limbs and his imageâ€”no sensation in it nor movement. Then he is placed in the earth and becomes a stinking, filthy corpse as he was initially a despised drop (nutfah). Then his limbs decay, his parts disintegrate, his bones rot, and he becomes scattered remains and fragments, and worms eat his parts, beginning with his pupils to pluck them out and his cheeks to cut them off, and with all his parts until he becomes dung in the bellies of worms and becomes a corpse from which animals flee and every human finds repulsive and flees from due to the intensity of the stench. The best of his states is that he returns to what he was and becomes earth from which cups are made and from which buildings are constructed, so he becomes non-existent after having been existent. And it becomes as if he had not flourished yesterday as a harvest, as he was in his first affair a long period. Would that he remained thusâ€”how excellent if he were left as earth! No, rather He revives him after long decay to experience severe trial, so he emerges from his grave after gathering his scattered parts, and emerges.

And you are nothing but a slave (abd) owned (mamluk) who cannot do anything. And whoever knows that, his arrogance must vanish. Its example: that the heedless one boasts of his strength, beauty, wealth, freedom, independence, spacious dwellings, and abundance of horses and servants, when two just witnesses testify against him before a fair judge that he is a slave (riq) to so-and-so and that his parents were owned (mamluk) by him, so that is known and the judge rules by it, then his owner (malik) comes and takes him, and takes all that is in his hand, and he with that fears that he will punish him and inflict harm upon him for his wastefulness in his wealth and his shortcoming in seeking his owner (malik) to know that he has an owner (malik). Then the slave (abd) looked and saw himself imprisoned in a dwelling that has been surrounded by snakes, scorpions, and vermin, and he is in every state in fear from each one of them, and he remains not owning himself nor his wealth nor knowing any way of escape at all. Do you think one in this state boasts of his power, wealth, strength, and perfection or humbles himself and submits? And this is the state of every intelligent person who becomes, for he sees himself thus, so he does not own his neck, body, limbs, and wealth, and he with that is among afflictions, desires, illnesses, and diseases that are like scorpions and snakes from which he fears destruction. So one in this state does not become arrogant with his strength and power since he knows that he has no power and no strength. This is the way of treating arrogance with external causes, and it is easier than treating arrogance with knowledge and action, for they are two perfections in the soul (nafs) worthy of rejoicing in them. Allah struck a similitude: a slave (abd) owned (mamluk) who cannot do anything, and one whom We have provided from Us a good provision, so he spends from it secretly and openly. Are they equal? Praise be to Allah. But most of them do not know.

The third category: Arrogance (Takabbur) towards the servants (of Allah); that is by magnifying oneself and belittling others, so his soul (Nafs) refuses to submit to them and calls him to elevate himself over them, thus he despises them, considers them insignificant, and disdains equality with them. And this, even though it is less than the first and second, is also great from two aspects; one of them: that arrogance (Kibr), honor (Izz), majesty (Azamah), and loftiness (Ala') are not fitting except for the capable King (Malik), so as for the owned slave (Abd Mamlook), weak, incapable, who is not able to do anything, then from where is arrogance fitting for his condition? Whenever a slave (Abd) becomes arrogant, he has contended with Allah the Exalted in an attribute that is not fitting except for His majesty (Jalal), and its example: that a boy takes the king's cap and places it on his head and sits on his throne, so how great is his deserving of hatred and how great is his targeting for disgrace and punishment! And how severe is his audacity towards his master (Mawla) and how ugly is what he has undertaken! And to this meaning is the allusion in His saying the Exalted "Majesty (Azamah) is My lower garment and grandeur (Kibriya') is My upper garment, so whoever contends with Me in them I will break him" meaning that it is specific to My attribute and not fitting except for Me, and the contender in it contends in an attribute from My attributes, and if arrogance (Kibr) over His servants is not fitting except for Him, then whoever is arrogant over His servants has wronged Him, since the one who despises the special servants of the king and uses them and elevates himself over them and monopolizes what is the king's right to monopolize from them is contending with him in some of his affair, even if his degree does not reach the degree of one who wanted to sit on his throne and monopolize his kingdom, so all creation are servants (Ibad) of Allah and to Him belongs majesty (Azamah) and grandeur (Kibriya') over them, so whoever is arrogant over a servant (Abd) from the servants (Ibad) of Allah has contended with Allah in His right. Indeed, the difference between this contention and the contention of Nimrod and Pharaoh, is the difference between contending with the king in belittling some of his slaves and using them and contending with him in the essence of kingship.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
The third category: Arrogance (Takabbur) towards the servants (of Allah); this is by magnifying oneself and belittling others, so his Soul (Nafs) refuses to submit to them and calls him to elevate himself over them, thus he despises them, considers them insignificant, and disdains equality with them. And this, even if it is less than the first and second, is also great from two aspects. The first: that arrogance (Kibr), honor (Izz), majesty (Azamah), and loftiness (Ala') are not fitting except for the King (Malik) who is capable (Qadir). As for the servant (Abd) who is owned (Mamluk), weak (Da'if), incapable (Ajiz), who cannot do anything, then from where does arrogance (Kibr) befit his state? So whenever a servant (Abd) becomes arrogant (Takabbur), he has contended with Allah the Exalted in an attribute that is not fitting except for His majesty (Jalal). Its example: that a boy (Ghulam) takes the king's cap (Qalansuwah) and places it on his head and sits on his throne (Sarir), so how great is his deserving of contempt (Maqt) and how great is his exposure to disgrace (Khizy) and punishment (Nikal)! And how severe is his audacity (Istijra') towards his master (Mawlah) and how ugly is what he has undertaken! And to this meaning is the allusion in His saying the Exalted: "Majesty (Azamah) is My lower garment (Izar) and arrogance (Kibriya') is My cloak (Rida'), so whoever contends with Me in them I will break him" meaning that it is specific to My attribute and not fitting except for Me, and the contender in it contends in an attribute from My attributes. And if arrogance (Kibr) over His servants (Ibad) is not fitting except for Him, then whoever is arrogant (Takabbur) over His servants (Ibad) has wronged Him, since the one who despises the special servants (Khawass) of the king's boys (Ghulman), uses them, elevates himself over them, and monopolizes what it is the king's right to monopolize from them, he is contending with him in some of his affair, even if his degree does not reach the degree of one who wanted to sit on his throne (Sarir) and monopolize his kingdom. So all creation (Khalq) are servants (Ibad) of Allah and to Him belongs majesty (Azamah) and arrogance (Kibriya') over them, so whoever is arrogant (Takabbur) over a servant (Abd) from the servants (Ibad) of Allah has contended with Allah in His right. Yes, the difference between this contention and the contention of Nimrod and Pharaoh is the difference between contending with the king in belittling some of his servants (Abid) and using them and contending with him in the foundation of kingship. The second aspect: by which the vileness of arrogance (Takabbur) towards the servants (of Allah) is magnified is that Allah the Exalted struck for it a parable, saying: "And Allah presents an example of two men: one of them is dumb (Abkam), unable to do anything, and he is a burden (Kall) upon his master (Mawlah) - wherever he directs him, he brings no good. Is he equal to one who commands justice (Adl) and is upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim)?" So the one arrogant (Mutakabbir) towards the servants (of Allah) is like the dumb (Abkam) who cannot do anything, and he is a burden (Kall) upon his master (Mawlah), meaning a heavy load upon him, wherever he directs him he brings no good. So is he equal to one who commands justice (Adl) and is upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim)? So the one arrogant (Mutakabbir) towards the servants (of Allah) does not command justice (Adl) nor is he upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim), rather he is like the dumb (Abkam) who cannot do anything, and he is a burden (Kall) upon his master (Mawlah), meaning a heavy load upon Allah the Exalted, wherever he directs him he brings no good. So is he equal to one who commands justice (Adl) and is upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim)? So the one arrogant (Mutakabbir) towards the servants (of Allah) does not command justice (Adl) nor is he upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim), rather he is like the dumb (Abkam) who cannot do anything, and he is a burden (Kall) upon his master (Mawlah), meaning a heavy load upon Allah the Exalted, wherever he directs him he brings no good. So is he equal to one who commands justice (Adl) and is upon a straight path (Sirat Mustaqim)?

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
If you say: What is the benefit of supplication (Dua) when divine decree (Qada) cannot be reversed? Know that from divine decree (Qada) is repelling affliction (Bala) through supplication (Dua), so supplication (Dua) is a cause for repelling affliction (Bala) and attracting mercy (Rahma) just as a shield is a cause for repelling an arrow and water is a cause for the emergence of plants from the earth. So just as the shield pushes the arrow and they repel each other, likewise supplication (Dua) and affliction (Bala) contend with each other. It is not a condition of acknowledging the divine decree (Qada) of Allah the Exalted to not carry weapons, and He the Exalted has said: 'Take your precautions' (Quran 4:71), and to not water the earth after sowing seeds, saying: If divine decree (Qada) preceded with growth, the seed will grow, and if it did not precede, it will not grow. Rather, linking causes (Asbab) to effects (Musabbabat) is the first divine decree (Qada) which is like the blink of an eye or it is nearer. And arranging the detailing of effects (Musabbabat) upon the details of causes (Asbab) with gradualness and measure is divine destiny (Qadar). And the One who decreed good decreed it with a cause, and the One who decreed evil decreed it to repel it with a cause. So there is no contradiction between these matters for one whose insight (Basira) has opened.

a.g: And Allah has extracted you from the wombs of your mothers not knowing a thing, and He made for you hearing and vision and intellect that perhaps you would be grateful.
Do they not see the birds controlled in the atmosphere of the sky? None holds them up except Allah. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.

And Allah has made for you from your homes a place of rest and made for you from the hides of the animals tents which you find light on your day of travel and your day of encampment; and from their wool, fur and hair is furnishing and enjoyment for a time.

And Allah has made for you, from that which He has created, shadows and has made for you from the mountains, shelters and has made for you garments which protect you from the heat and garments which protect you from your [enemy in] battle. Thus does He complete His favor upon you that you might submit [to Him].
But if they turn away, [O Muhammad] - then only upon you is [responsibility for] clear notification.
They recognize the favor of Allah; then they deny it. And most of them are disbelievers.
And [mention] the Day when We will resurrect from every nation a witness. Then it will not be permitted to the disbelievers [to apologize or make excuses], nor will they be asked to appease [Allah].
And when those who wronged see the punishment, it will not be lightened for them, nor will they be reprieved.

And when those who associated others with Allah see their "partners," they will say," Our Lord, these are our partners [to You] whom we used to invoke besides You." But they will throw at them the statement, "Indeed, you are liars."
And they will impart to Allah that Day [their] submission, and lost from them is what they used to invent.
Those who disbelieved and averted [others] from the way of Allah - We will increase them in punishment over [their] punishment for what corruption they were causing.

And [mention] the Day when We will resurrect among every nation a witness over them from themselves. And We will bring you, [O Muhammad], as a witness over your nation. And We have sent down to you the Book as clarification for all things and as guidance and mercy and good tidings for the Muslims.
Indeed, Allah orders justice and good conduct and giving to relatives and forbids immorality and bad conduct and oppression. He admonishes you that perhaps you will be reminded.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
[12] A narration that Khalid bin 'Uqbah came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: Recite the Quran to me. So he recited to him: 'Indeed, Allah commands justice (al-'adl) and excellence (al-ihsan) and giving to near kin (dhi al-qurba), and forbids indecency (al-fahsha') and evil (al-munkar) and oppression (al-baghy). He admonishes you that perhaps you may remember.' He said: Repeat. So he repeated. Then he said: Indeed, it has sweetness (hulwah), and indeed upon it is freshness (talawah), and indeed its lower part is overflowing (mughtadiq), and indeed its upper part is fruitful (muthmir), and no human says this. Ibn 'Abd al-Barr mentioned it in al-Isti'ab without chain, and al-Bayhaqi narrated it in al-Shu'ab from the narration of Ibn 'Abbas with a good chain, except that he said al-Walid bin al-Mughirah instead of Khalid bin 'Uqbah, and likewise Ibn Ishaq mentioned it in al-Sirah similarly.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
And Al-Fudayl ibn Iyad said: It is fitting for the bearer of the Quran that he should have no need of anyone, nor of the caliphs or those below them; rather, the needs of creation should be directed to him. He also said: The bearer of the Quran is the bearer of the banner of Islam, so it is not fitting that he should play around with those who play around, nor be heedless with those who are heedless, nor engage in idle talk with those who engage in idle talk, out of reverence for the right of the Quran. And Sufyan al-Thawri said: When a man recites the Quran, the angel places it between his eyes. And Amr ibn Maymun said: Whoever opens a Quran when he prays the morning prayer and recites one hundred verses from it, Allah the Exalted will raise for him the equivalent of the deeds of all the people of the world. And it is narrated that (Khalid ibn Uqbah came to the Messenger of Allah ï·º and said: Recite the Quran to me. So he recited to him: 'Indeed, Allah commands justice and excellence (Ihsan) and giving to relatives, and He forbids immorality and wrong and oppression; He admonishes you that perhaps you will be reminded.' Then he said to him: Repeat it. Chapter Four: On Excellence (Ihsan) in Transactions. And Allah the Exalted has commanded justice (Adl) and excellence (Ihsan) together. Justice (Adl) is the cause of salvation only, and it flows in trade like capital. Excellence (Ihsan) is the cause of triumph and attainment of happiness, and it flows in trade like profit. One is not considered among the heedless who is content in worldly transactions with his capital, so likewise in the transactions of the Hereafter. Therefore, it is not fitting for the religious person to limit himself to justice (Adl) and avoiding oppression (Zulm) and abandon the doors of excellence (Ihsan). And Allah has said: 'And do good (Ahsin) as Allah has done good (Ahsan) to you.' And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Indeed, Allah commands justice (Adl) and excellence (Ihsan).' And He the Glorified said: 'Indeed, the mercy of Allah is near to the doers of good (Muhsinin).' And we mean by excellence (Ihsan) doing what benefits the transactor, and it is not obligatory upon him, but it is a favor from him. For the obligatory enters into the chapter of justice (Adl) and abandoning oppression (Zulm), and we have mentioned it. And the rank of excellence (Ihsan) is attained by one of six matters: The first is in overcharging (Mughabana). So one should not overcharge his companion with what is not customarily overcharged. As for the basis of overcharging (Mughabana), it is permitted because selling is for profit, and that is not possible except with some overcharging. But moderation is observed in it. If the buyer offers an increase over the customary profit, either due to intense desire or intense need for it at the moment, then one should refrain from accepting it, and that is from excellence (Ihsan). As long as there is no deception, taking the increase is not oppression (Zulm).

a.g: And fulfill the covenant of Allah when you have taken it, [O believers], and do not break oaths after their confirmation while you have made Allah, over you, a witness. Indeed, Allah knows what you do.

And do not be like she who untwisted her spun thread after it was strong [by] taking your oaths as [means of] deceit between you because one community is more plentiful [in number or wealth] than another community. Allah only tries you thereby. And He will surely make clear to you on the Day of Resurrection that over which you used to differ.
And if Allah had willed, He could have made you [of] one religion, but He causes to stray whom He wills and guides whom He wills. And you will surely be questioned about what you used to do.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: The Lawful and Prohibited
And we allow that Allah may decree a cause by which He destroys the creation entirely, so their worldly life is lost and they go astray in their religion, for He misguides whom He wills and guides whom He wills, and causes death whom He wills and gives life whom He wills. But we consider the matter proceeding according to what is customary from the established way (Sunnah) of Allah the Exalted in sending the prophets for the rectification of the religion and the worldly life.

a.g: And do not take your oaths as [means of] deceit between you, lest a foot slip after it was [once] firm, and you would taste evil [in this world] for what [people] you diverted from the way of Allah, and you would have [in the Hereafter] a great punishment.
And do not exchange the covenant of Allah for a small price. Indeed, what is with Allah is best for you, if only you could know.
Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting. And We will surely give those who were patient their reward according to the best of what they used to do.

And as for the knowledge that is fruitful for this state, it is the knowledge that what is abandoned is insignificant in comparison to what is taken, like the knowledge of the merchant that the exchange is better than the sold item, so he desires it. And if this knowledge is not realized, it cannot be imagined that the desire for the sold item will vanish. Similarly, whoever knows that what is with Allah remains and that the Hereafter is better and more lasting, meaning its essence is better in itself and more lasting, just as jewels are better and more lasting than snow, for example. And it is not difficult for the owner of snow to sell it for jewels and pearls. Thus is the example of this world and the Hereafter: this world is like snow placed in the sun, constantly melting to extinction, and the Hereafter is like a jewel that has no perishing. So according to the strength of certainty and knowledge of the disparity between this world and the Hereafter, the desire for selling and transaction strengthens, until indeed whoever has strong certainty sells his soul (Nafs) and his wealth, as Allah the Exalted said: "Indeed, Allah has purchased from the believers their souls (Anfus) and their wealth in exchange for Paradise for them." Then He clarified that their transaction is profitable, so He said: "So rejoice in your transaction which you have contracted." So what is needed from knowledge in asceticism (Zuhd) is only this amount: that the Hereafter is better and more lasting. And one may know that yet not be able to abandon this world, either due to weakness in his knowledge and certainty, or due to the domination of desire (Shahwa) in the moment over him and being overpowered in the hand of Satan, or due to his deception by the promises of Satan in procrastination day after day until death snatches him and nothing remains with him except regret after the passing: and to the definition of the baseness of this world, the indication is in His saying: "Say, the enjoyment of this world is little." ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
As for the action, then say with your tongue: 'I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan (Shaytan).' Thus did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) command that it be said during anger [23]. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), when Aisha became angry, would take her by the nose and say: 'O little Aisha, say: O Allah, Lord of the Prophet Muhammad, forgive me my sin, remove the anger of my heart (Qalb), and deliver me from misleading trials (Fitnah)' [24]. It is recommended to say that. If it does not cease with that, then sit if you are standing, and lie down if you are sitting, and draw near to the earth from which you were created, so that you may recognize thereby the lowliness of your soul (Nafs). And seek through sitting and lying down tranquility, for the cause of anger is heat, and the cause of heat is movement. Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Anger is an ember kindled in the heart (Qalb)' [25]. Have you not seen the swelling of his veins and the redness of his eyes? So if any of you finds something of that, then if he is standing, let him sit, and if he is sitting, let him lie down. If it does not cease with that, then let him perform ablution (Wudu) with cold water or bathe, for fire is not extinguished except by water. Indeed, he (peace be upon him) said: 'When one of you becomes angry, let him perform ablution (Wudu) with water, for indeed anger is from fire' [26]. And in a narration: 'Anger is from Satan (Shaytan), and Satan (Shaytan) was created from fire, and fire is only extinguished by water, so when one of you becomes angry, let him perform ablution (Wudu).' And Ibn Abbas said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'And when you become angry, be silent' [27]. And Abu Huraira said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), when he became angry while standing, would sit, and when he became angry while sitting, would lie down, and his anger would depart [28].

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
And when you say 'I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan (Shaytan)', know that he is your enemy and lies in wait to divert your Heart (Qalb) from Allah the Exalted, out of envy toward you for your intimate conversation (Munajat) with Allah the Exalted and your prostration (Sujud) to Him, even though he was cursed due to a single prostration he abandoned and was not granted success in it. And your seeking refuge (Isti'adha) in Allah the Glorified from him is by abandoning what he loves and replacing it with what Allah the Exalted loves, not merely by your statement. For if one whom a predator or enemy intends to devour or kill says 'I seek refuge from you with that impregnable fortress' while remaining in his place, that will not benefit him; rather, nothing will grant him refuge except changing his location. Likewise, one who follows the desires (Shahawat) that are the pleasures of Satan and the displeasures of the Most Merciful (Al-Rahman) will not be helped by mere speech. So let his statement be accompanied by the determination (Al-'Azm) to seek refuge with the fortress of Allah the Exalted from the evil of Satan, and his fortress is 'There is no god but Allah (La ilaha illa Allah)', as He the Exalted said in what our Prophet (peace be upon him) reported: 'There is no god but Allah is my fortress, so whoever enters my fortress is safe from my punishment.' And the one who takes refuge in it has no object of worship except Allah the Glorified. As for one who takes his desire (Hawa) as his god, he is in the arena of Satan, not in the fortress of Allah the Exalted. And know that among his stratagems is to distract you in your prayer (Salah) with remembrance (Dhikr) of the Hereafter and planning good deeds to prevent you from understanding what you recite. Know that everything that distracts you from understanding the meanings of your recitation is whispering (Waswas). For the movement of the tongue is not the intended goal; rather, the intended goal is their meanings.

And the whispering (Waswasah) of the Satan (Shaytan) is not erased from the Heart (Qalb) except by the Remembrance (Dhikr) of other than what he whispers about, because when the Remembrance (Dhikr) of something occurs in the Heart (Qalb), what was previously in it disappears. But everything other than Allah the Exalted and other than what is related to Him may also be a field for the Satan (Shaytan), and the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is what secures its side and makes known that there is no field for the Satan (Shaytan) in it. And a thing is not treated except by its opposite, and the opposite of all the whisperings (Waswasah) of the Satan (Shaytan) is the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah through seeking refuge (Isti'adha) and disavowal of power and strength, and that is the meaning of your saying: 'I seek refuge (A'udhu) in Allah from the accursed Satan (Shaytan) (Al-Rajim)', and 'There is no power nor strength except with Allah the Most High, the Most Great'. And that is not within the capability except of the God-fearing (Muttaqun) upon whom the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted predominates. And indeed, the Satan (Shaytan) circulates around them in times of lapses (Falatat) by way of stealth. Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who fear Allah (Yattaquna) â€“ when an impulse (Ta'if) from the Satan (Shaytan) touches them, they remember (Tadhakkara) and at once they have insight (Mubsirun).' And Mujahid said regarding the meaning of Allah the Exalted's saying: 'From the evil of the retreating whisperer (Al-Waswas Al-Khannas)', he said: 'He is spread out over the Heart (Qalb), so when Allah the Exalted is remembered (Dhikr), he retreats (Khannasa) and contracts, and when he is heedless (Ghafla), he spreads out over his Heart (Qalb).' So the chasing away between the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted and the whispering (Waswasah) of the Satan (Shaytan) is like the chasing away between light (Nur) and darkness (Zulmah), and between night (Layl) and day (Nahar). And Anas said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, the Satan (Shaytan) places his snout (Khurtum) on the Heart (Qalb) of the son of Adam, so if he remembers (Dhikr) Allah the Exalted, he retreats (Khannasa), and if he forgets (Nasiya) Allah the Exalted, he swallows (Iltqama) his Heart (Qalb).'

The Angel (Malak) is an expression for a creation that Allah the Exalted created, its affair being the outpouring of good, imparting knowledge, unveiling truth, promising good, and commanding righteousness. He created it and subjugated it for that. And the Satan (Shaytan) is an expression for a creation whose affair is the opposite of that, which is promising evil, commanding indecency, and frightening when intending good with poverty. So whispering (Waswasa) is in opposition to inspiration (Ilham), and Satan is in opposition to the Angel, and success (Tawfiq) is in opposition to abandonment. To this is the allusion in His saying the Exalted: 'And of all things We created pairs' (51:49). For all existents are opposing, paired except Allah the Exalted, for He is singular with no opposite; rather, He is the One True (Al-Wahid Al-Haqq), Creator of all pairs. So the Heart (Qalb) is pulled between Satan and the Angel. Then he recited His saying the Exalted: 'Satan threatens you with poverty and commands you to indecency' (2:268). And Al-Hasan said: 'They are but two thoughts (Hamman) that roam in the Heart: a thought from Allah the Exalted and a thought from the enemy. And for the pulling of the Heart between these two dominators, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'The Heart of the believer is between two fingers from the fingers of the Most Merciful.' ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Then He informed that He has two servants: He loves one of them, and his name is Jibril and the Spirit of Holiness (Ruh al-Qudus) and the Trustworthy (Al-Amin), and he is with Him beloved, obeyed, trustworthy, and firmly established; and He detests the other, and his name is Iblis, and he is the accursed one, granted respite until the Day of Recompense (Yawm al-Din). Then He attributed guidance to Jibril, so the Exalted said: 'Say: The Spirit of Holiness (Ruh al-Qudus) has brought it down from your Lord with truth' {} and He said: 'He casts the Spirit (Ruh) from His command upon whom He wills of His servants' {} and He attributed misguidance to Iblis, so He said: 'To lead astray from His path' {} and misguidance is preventing the servants from reaching the ultimate wisdom. So see how He attributed it to the servant upon whom He is angry, and guidance is leading them to the ultimate goal, so see how He attributed it to the servant whom He loved. And you have in custom an example for it: if a king needs someone to give him drink and someone to perform cupping and clean the courtyard of his house from filth, and he has two servants, then he does not assign for cupping and cleaning except the ugliest and most base of them, and he does not entrust carrying the drink and perfume except to the best, most complete, and most beloved of them to him. And it is not fitting for you to say: 'This is my action, and was not his action without my action?' For you have erred when you attributed that to yourself; rather, it is He who directed your motivation to specify the disliked action with the disliked person and the beloved action with the beloved person, completing justice. For His justice (Adl) is sometimes accomplished through matters in which you have no involvement, and sometimes it is accomplished in you, for you are also from His actions. So your motivation, your capability, your knowledge, your action, and all the causes of your movements in expression are His action which He arranged with justice, an arrangement from which balanced actions issue, except that you see only yourself, so you think that what appears upon you in the world of witnessing (Alam al-Shahadah) has no cause.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
Whenever the Heart (Qalb) that dominates at the time of death is love of family, children, wealth, residence, property, companions, and friends, then this is a man whose loves are all in the worldly life (Dunya). Thus, the worldly life is his paradise, since paradise is an expression for the place that gathers all loves. His death is an exit from paradise and a barrier between him and what he desires, and the state of one who is barred between him and what he desires is not hidden. If he has no beloved except Allah, the Exalted, and except His Remembrance (Dhikr), knowledge of Him, and contemplation of Him, and the worldly life and its attachments distract him from the Beloved, then the worldly life is his prison, because prison is an expression for the place that prevents the imprisoned from finding relief in his loves. His death is a standing before his Beloved and a liberation from prison, and the state of one who escapes from prison and is left between him and his Beloved without any barrier or disturbance is not hidden. This is the first thing that everyone who departs from the worldly life encounters immediately after his death from reward and punishment, apart from what Allah has prepared for His righteous servants that no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and no human heart has conceived, and apart from what Allah, the Exalted, has prepared for those who preferred the worldly life over the Hereafter and were pleased with it and felt secure in itâ€”from shackles, chains, fetters, and various kinds of disgrace and punishment. So we ask Allah, the Exalted, to cause us to die as Muslims and join us with the righteous, and there is no hope in the answer to this supplication except by acquiring the love of Allah, the Exalted, and there is no way to it except by removing the love of other than Him from the Heart (Qalb) and cutting off attachments to everything other than Allah, the Exalted, from status, wealth, and homeland. a.g: And Allah presents an example: a city which was safe and secure, its provision coming to it in abundance from every location, but it denied the favors of Allah. So Allah made it taste the envelopment of hunger and fear for what they had been doing.
And there had certainly come to them a Messenger from among themselves, but they denied him; so punishment overtook them while they were wrongdoers.
Then eat of what Allah has provided for you [which is] lawful and good. And be grateful for the favor of Allah, if it is [indeed] Him that you worship.

He has only forbidden to you dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah. But whoever is forced [by necessity], neither desiring [it] nor transgressing [its limit] - then indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
And do not say about what your tongues assert of untruth, "This is lawful and this is unlawful," to invent falsehood about Allah. Indeed, those who invent falsehood about Allah will not succeed.
[It is but] a brief enjoyment, and they will have a painful punishment.
And to those who are Jews We have prohibited that which We related to you before. And We did not wrong them [thereby], but they were wronging themselves.
Then, indeed your Lord, to those who have done wrong out of ignorance and then repent after that and correct themselves - indeed, your Lord, thereafter, is Forgiving and Merciful.
Indeed, Abraham was a [comprehensive] leader, devoutly obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth, and he was not of those who associate others with Allah.

a.g: And if you punish [an enemy, O believers], punish with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed. But if you are patient - it is better for those who are patient.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
And Allah the Exalted said: 'And if you retaliate, then retaliate with the like of that with which you were afflicted. But if you are patient, it is indeed better for the patient ones.' And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Maintain ties with the one who cuts you off, give to the one who deprives you, and pardon the one who wrongs you.' And I saw in the Gospel that Jesus son of Mary (peace be upon him) said: 'It was said to you before: An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth, but I say to you: Do not resist evil, but whoever strikes your right cheek, turn to him the other also; and whoever takes your cloak, give him your tunic; and whoever compels you to go one mile, go with him two.' And all of that commands patience upon harm, for patience upon the harm of people is from the highest levels of patience because in it the motivator of religion and the motivator of desire and anger all cooperate.

a.g: And be patient, [O Muhammad], and your patience is not but through Allah. And do not grieve over them and do not be in distress over what they conspire.
Indeed, Allah is with those who fear Him and those who are doers of good.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And they are forty righteous ones or thirty men whose hearts (Qulub) are upon the certainty (Yaqin) like Ibrahim, the intimate friend (Khalil) of the Most Merciful, peace be upon him. No man among them dies until Allah has raised up one to succeed him. And know, O my brother, that they do not curse anything, nor harm it, nor belittle it, nor act arrogantly toward it, nor envy anyone, nor are they preoccupied with the worldly life (Dunya). They are the best of people in goodness, the most gentle in disposition, and the most generous in soul (Nafs). Their sign is generosity, their nature is cheerfulness, and their attribute is safety. They are not today in fear and tomorrow in heedlessness, but rather they are constant in their outward state, and between them and their Lord, the raging winds and galloping horses do not reach them. Their hearts ascend with delight to Allah and longing for Him, and they are foremost in racing toward good deeds. "Those are the party of Allah. Indeed, the party of Allah are the successful." The narrator said: So I said: O Abu al-Darda, I have not heard of a description more difficult for me than that description, and how can I attain it? He said: Between you and being in its broadest scope is nothing except that you hate the worldly life (Dunya). For if you hate the worldly life, you turn to the love (Hubb) of the Hereafter (Akhirah), and according to the measure of your love for the Hereafter, you abstain from the worldly life, and according to that measure, you perceive what benefits you. And when Allah knows from a servant (Abd) good seeking, He pours upon him correctness and surrounds him with protection. And know, O son of my brother, that this is in the Book of Allah, the Exalted, the Revealed: "Indeed, Allah is with those who fear (Ittaqaw) and those who are doers of good (Muhsinun)." Yahya ibn Kathir said: So we reflected on that, and the delighters have not delighted in anything like the love (Hubb) of Allah and seeking His pleasure. O Allah, make us among the lovers of those who love You, O Lord of the worlds, for none is suitable for Your love except whom You have approved. And may Allah bless our master Muhammad and his family and companions and grant them peace.
